text:
I'd expect Wikilambda to fare better than Wolfram Alpha because it's open. Wolfram Alpha is basically a showcase or a demo. It's something that Wolfram makes public to show off their technology. But you can't build anything on top of Wolfram Alpha. And therefore the people who do use Wolfram Alpha productively cannot integrate it into a publicly visible tool.
Open tools don't have that problem. Python acquired a reputation because its early users made their Python-based work open as well. It is not difficult to find answers to the question "what can I do with Python?"
